reasoning:
Centrality: The critique targets a recurring rhetorical/structural move in §2 (“even if everyone approves/gets what they want, big value loss is possible”) that supports the broader ‘fragility’ intuition, but it does not directly engage the essay’s more technical Section 3 argument that most plausible value functions are fussy. So undermining this move would weaken a substantial pillar (the intuitive case for fragility), but not collapse the whole position.

Strength: It successfully pressures the authors to clarify why universal approval isn’t strong evidence against ‘moral catastrophe’ in their setup, and it identifies a tension: the essay uses “everyone approves” to make the scenario seem non-dystopian while asserting large moral error without giving a metaethical/epistemic account. However, the position can likely patch this: the authors can say (and sometimes imply) that approval is weak evidence because preference adaptation, motivated cognition, path dependence, and moral uncertainty mean endorsement can persist despite error; also, their argument doesn’t require ‘strong moral realism’ so much as the possibility of moral truth diverging from widespread attitudes under a VNM-representable ordering. Hence it weakens rather than refutes.

Correctness: Mostly right that “everyone approves” is irrelevant to the defined value function unless supplemented with a story linking approval to value, and that the essay could better justify why endorsement might anti-track moral truth even under abundance. Some overstatement/possible misread: the essay isn’t clearly “smuggling” preference metaethics; it explicitly defines value via a betterness relation and uses approval mainly to illustrate non-obvious flaws, not as evidential support. Also, “universal approval is strong evidence (on many listed perspectives)” is plausible but not generally true (many listed perspectives allow mass error).

Clarity: The objection is clearly stated, with a step-by-step structure and a concrete burden-shift (either defend endorsement-weakness or drop the rhetorical condition).

Dead weight: Low; nearly all sentences contribute to the single line of critique.

Single issue: Focuses on one coherent issue (the role of universal approval/what it evidentially contributes).

Overall: A useful, insightful pressure on one motivating strand, but it doesn’t seriously undermine the essay’s main technical case and is partly patchable; thus moderate-to-low overall impact.
title: Universal approval in ideal conditions undermines claims of systematic moral error
